filpkart.comment: This is a good phone with great build quality, excellent screen (color accurate and silky smooth to touch), nice camera (under good lighting). The Lollipop OS is far improved from its predecessor, but still lags behind customized versions of Samsung etc in terms of intuitiveness. Things are all "hidden" under the hood and, you should know how use it from else where. eg: when calls comes, there are multiple options, 1) take the call, 2) reject 3) reject with message etc, this can be done by swiping right/left or up/down. But the problem is, that none of these option are shown on the screen at first. You need to fiddle around to see how to even take a call !. Once you get used to it, it is easy, but there is a learning curve, which I think could have been easily avoided. The biggest problem however is the excessive radiation (SAR) which is 1.51 against the limit of 1.6 required in India. Note that Samsung S3 has only 0.55 SAR. That is a lot of difference. If you are sensitive to RF exposure, please be aware about this. I have also seen the phone going out of network for a few seconds and coming back for no apparent reason. Battery life is not very great (hits 50% in a day with minimal usage). However idle backup with 2G is exceptional, lasts 3 days to hit 50% battery, ie may last up to 6 days! Once you put in 3G, it consumes 2-3 times more power even under idle (mobile data/wifi off)

This brought me to think if the piece I got was used by someone (although for a short period). Not sure if I can trust Flipkart on that anymore. The phone looks good. Can be held and easily handled by one hand - I don't like those excessively huge handsets. Also, this is my first Android phone so my experience will be affected by both the phone and the OS's performance. Performance:- The battery backup is awful. I need to recharge it frequently - Once every 15-16 hours after normal use. This is when I play no games at all. I have a few apps, and I browse, that's all. I was travelling the other day and there was a disruption in connectivity. I think some apps were trying to connect and suddenly the phone went haywire! Some random things opened on their own on the screen, the flash turned on, and the touchscreen stopped taking any inputs from me. Even the power off button needs an input from the touch screen, and the battery is not detachable so I could not just remove it and shut the thing down. I somehow managed to forcefully power it off after trying for 10-15 minutes. I have also kept the vibration off, but the phone still vibrates when I type. Other features are okay. filpkart.comment: I'm writing this review after personally using Samsung Galaxy Grand, Sony Xperia C, and the iPad. My intent behind buying this phone was just to have a decent phone capable of performing regular functions nicely, and with ease. I didn't want any extra-ordinarily spec'd phone, which might have heating issues, poor battery life, and low call quality, etc. So, I decided to settle for this. And, to my surprise, I'm not let down by my decision of buying the Moto G2. On papers, the specs might not seem to fancy when compared with similarly priced phones from other brands but, this phone is a GEM IN HANDS. Here's what I have to say: First and foremost, the look and feel of this device (obviously without any sort of protection) is amazing, and it feels great to hold this device in hand. Secondly, the User Interface is simple and elegant, with no nonsensical customizations from the manufacturer. Thirdly, The sound quality, call quality, touch and everything else is simply amazing. Also, the phone has a lot of RAM to spare despite having too many apps installed and running in the background. So, not a concern at all. The only point where it lacks slightly is the battery backup, which could have been better. But, considering the performance of today's phones, I'll definitely say that it's at par, or only better.
